name: Ole
summary: I've been working with Alfresco for 3.5-4 years. I haven't had much luck with the community in the past, but this changed last year and I decided to go all in and participate as I realised that I could make a difference.
contributions:
• Very active in the IRC channel, helping out answering questions, and a couple of times doing PoC projects for others who are struggling.
  • Write a tutorial about the Aikau framework.
  • Mavenize the old Alfresco SDK.
  • Dedicate 6 weeks of my free time to work on Alfresco related projects.
  • Help test 5.0.a's newly mavenized build process before release
  • Deeply involved in the development of Alfresco SDK 2.0 with RAD support
  • Participated in Tech Talk Live.
  • Working on an update of the Danish language pack for 5.0.a.

summary: Alfresco consultant since 2007.

name: Tahir
summary:
I've been working very long on Alfresco as a Developer. Started with version 2.2. and am still going hard with the latest version.

The first 3 years with Alfresco I was working for a company, then I started my own firm. After my own firm I realized how important the community is. So then I started contributing as in Jira fixes, blogs and after a while on StackOverflow.

After the first Dashlet competition I started writing addons and pieces of code for Alfresco & the community. Now a days I'm developing a lot of stuff, mainly custom modules and I try to blog once in a while.
contributions:
• Addons: Alfresco Advanced Folder Search, Alfresco AND Search, YouTube Dashlet, Move2Folder
    • Blogs: http://www.contezza.nl/blog, http://blog.mitco-solutions.com/
  • Patches: Mostly found in the JIRA, SSO Kerberos fix, WebDavLock fix, Multitentant fix for using an email as username
  • StackOverflow:

name: Adei

name: Aingaran
summary: Did my first Alfresco implementation in 2006. Loved the technology so much, I started by one man consulting gig called Zaizi in 2007. Today Zaizi is one of the biggest Alfresco partners in the world with the highest number Alfresco certified engineers outside of Alfresco. Alfresco EMEA Partner of the year 2012 & 2013.
contributions:

name: Jeff
summary: Have been working with Alfresco since its first release and continue to do so for clients around the world. Looking forward to helping ensure the software continues to be the world's leading open source ECM platform.
contributions:
• Wrote the Alfresco Developer Guide.
  • Every now and then I blog at ecmarchitect.com where you can get tips, tricks, and tutorials for Alfresco.

name: Heiko
summary:
Formed the first alfresco partner team in germany (@dmc.de).

Founder of ecm4u and ecm-market - we provide supported, maintained alfresco modules, alfresco virtual appliance and we run and maintain tens of alfresco sites we customized for our customers.
contributions:
• created and maintained the first german alfresco forum (which was handed over to Alfresco later when Germany was of interest)
  • alfresco patches module with fixes for several alfresco community versions

name: Prvoslav
summary: I am a CTO of yanado.com, a great task management tool that lives inside Gmail. Also an Alfresco developer for 5 years, implementing Alfresco in companies, maintaining and developing new features for clients.
contributions: Recently I have started a blog called alfrescoBlog.com where I tell about email tracking inside alfresco, like yesware or getSignals is, and other Alfresco related topics.

name: Charles
summary: During my studies (10 years ago), I was an active member of my LUG. My first job was in a company specialized in open sourced solutions. In 2004, I started working in ECM with major products like Documentum and IBM FileNet. In 2006, I started exploring Alfresco as I felt it could be the open sourced ECM solutions I was dreaming of ;-)
contributions:
• Active participation in French forums
  • Writing blog posts at http://charles.torda.net when I have time
  • Explaining to a local business group (Nantes area, France) what is Alfresco and what we can do with it
  • Contributing to Alfresco Jira (MNT-9755, ACE-1405)
  • I also produced two Alfresco extensions (Image Finder, My Network dashlet)... but they need to be updated

name: Andreas
summary: Freelance developer/consultant working with Alfresco since 2007.

• Author of various blogposts, extensions and patches

name: Marcus
summary: I'm an Alfresco consultant working for the Alfresco partner Redpill Linpro in Sweden. I have been working with alfresco for a few years and I've always had much help from community at the forums and blog posts etc.
contributions:
• I'm trying to answer questions on the forum when they are within my area of expertise.
  • Since 2013 I've been in charge of the open source project which supplies a simple way to integrate online editing with LibreOffice from Alfresco Share.
  • Since this year I'm also involved in the translation project at Crowdin where I together with other people translate Alfresco + RM into Swedish.
  • When working with new clients in my work I always try to find parts of the work that could be useful for other people. I have created some repos on github where such content has been published. So far most of it is without documentation, but that will follow when time allows.

name: Ben
contributions:
• active role in the Alfresco forums
  • reported bugs in Alfresco Community to Alfresco

name: Ashley
summary: I've been involved on-and-off with Alfresco development for a number of years in my current role at Surevine. Over those years I have been heavily involved in the development and deployment of a number of extensions for Alfresco.
contributions:
• Some of developed extensions are open source and some currently in the process of being open sourced
  • I presented at Alfresco DevCon (when they were still called that) a few years back and earned myself a t-shirt! :)

name: Bindu
summary: I am the chief architect at Zia Consulting, which is a Platinum Parter of Alfresco. We have been partner of the year a couple of times. As a platinum partner we can't work on community projects through work. However, there is nothing stopping folks working on community related projects in our spare time :)
contributions:
• I enjoy hanging out on IRC and answering questions if I can. I presented a dev environment we built during TTL #69 that I hope inspired the new RAD stuff in the 2.0 SDK at least a little bit.
  • I have also presented some lightning talks at DevCon/Summit and will be presenting a full session at Summit in SF and London this year that I hope will be interesting to (and advocating for) the community.

name: Gloria
summary: I am the Localisation Manager at Alfresco, managing the terminology and localisation of Alfresco products into the core official languages (French, German, Italian, Spanish, Japanese, Dutch, Russian, Norwegian, Brazilian Portuguese and Simplified Chinese). The term lists and translation memories are available for members of the community upon request.

name: Gabriele
summary: Former Principal Architect, now WW Manager at Alfresco Software.

contributions:
• alfresco-boxes

  • proto-athena

name: David
summary:
I've been working on Share and the APIs it uses for 4.5 years, after joining Alfresco's engineering team. I've touched most areas of Share, its APIs, but calendar, date/time and localisation and hybrid sync issues keep finding their way to my desk. I come from a web development background, so love the fact that client side technologies just won't stand still.

Recently I've been working on moving existing Share functionality to Aikau, the 5.0 search improvements as well as background tasks like development environment improvements, bringing in Grunt, simplifying maven usage and the way we run UI unit tests.
contributions:
• I blog at http://blogs.alfresco.com/wp/dwebster/.
  • I have code at https://github.com/davidcognite.
  • I try and make code to the Summits, where I usually present a session or two on new Share developments and enjoy the hack-a-thons.
